abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic and Public
            Sector Capacity Building Project in Cambodia were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included: the
            working relationship between the Bank and the implementing
            agency seems to have been severely strained at times and any
            future projects would need to be accompanied by strong
            efforts to rebuild mutual trust at leadership level. The
            project was also destabilized by the turnover in key
            personnel within the project management unit and at the
            Bank. The project was aligned with and supported declared
            government reform objectives at the time of appraisal.
            However, the appraisal team misjudged the government's
            commitment to implement the reforms advocated by the Bank.
            The Bank should have had a better understanding of the
            government reform agenda as outlined in the Strategy to
            rationalize the civil service (2001) and the National
            Program for Administrative Reform (2000 and 2004). There is
            now, by several accounts, a limited need to increase the
            supply of generic training opportunities for the public
            sector. Where training support is considered necessary, a
            better strategy for the future would be to focus efforts on
            the specific job requirements in individual ministries and
            reform processes. Additionally, there is the potential for
            Council for Administrative Reform (CAR) to develop its role
            as a coordinator of civil service training. In the case of
            this project, compliance with Monitoring and Evaluation
            (M&E), particularly progress reporting, needed to be of
            a higher standard. An operational project advisory board and
            a better functioning reporting system may have identified
            emerging problems and led to adjustments to the project at
            an earlier stage.
